elements.content: The targeted synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with open metal sites, following reticular chemistry rules, provides a straightforward methodology toward the development of advanced porous materials especially for gas storage/separation applications. Using a palladated tetracarboxylate metalloligand as a 4-connected node, we succeeded in synthesizing the first heterobimetallic In­(III)/Pd­(II)-based MOF with square-octahedron (soc) topology. The new MOF, formulated as [In3O­(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]·n­(solv) (1), features the oxo-centered trinuclear clusters, [In3(μ3-O)­(−COO)6], acting as trigonal-prismatic 6-connected nodes that linked together with the metalloligand trans-[PdCl2(PDC)2] (L 4– ) (PDC: pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate) to form a 3D network. After successful activation of 1 using supercritical CO2, high-resolution microporous analysis revealed the presence of small micropores (5.8 Å) with BET area of 795 m2 g–1 and total pore volume of 0.35 cm3 g–1. The activated solid shows high gravimetric (92.3 cm3 g–1) and volumetric (120.9 cm3 cm–3) CO2 uptake at 273 K and 1 bar as well as high CO2/CH4 (15.4 for a 50:50 molar mixture) and CO2/N2 (131.7 for a 10:90 molar mixture) selectivity, with moderate Q st 0 for CO2 (29.8 kJ mol–1). Slight modifications of the synthesis conditions led to the formation of a different MOF with an anionic framework, having a chemical formula [Me2NH2]­[In­(L)]·n(solv) (2). This MOF is constructed from pseudotetrahedral, mononuclear [In­(−COO)4] nodes bridged by four L 4– linkers, resulting in a 3D network with PtS topology.

elements.content: Using reticular chemistry rules, a new and highly porous heterometallic In­(III)−Pd­(II) metal−organic framework with square-octahedron (soc) topology was designed and successfully synthesized. The pores of this MOF are decorated with −PdCl2− moieties and in combination with unsaturated In­(III) sites result in high CO2 uptake with high CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivity.
elements.clean_text: Using reticular chemistry rules, a new and highly porous heterometallic In(III)-Pd(II) metal-organic framework with square-octahedron (soc) topology was designed and successfully synthesized. The pores of this MOF are decorated with -PdCl2- moieties and in combination with unsaturated In(III) sites result in high CO2 uptake with high CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivity.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) constitute a novel class of open-framework crystalline solids formed by cooperative assembly of metal cations or clusters (termed secondary building units or SBU) with organic linkers. Because the SBUs can have certain preferred coordination geometries, self-assembly of these connecting building units with organic ligands of a particular shape, can lead to the development of MOFs with predictable structures. This is the foundation of the so-called “reticular chemistry” approach and represents an important synthetic tool toward the development of MOFs with predetermined structures and pore systems in terms of size, shape, and functionality. It is now well-documented that MOFs can be truly designed and therefore provide unique opportunities for developing tailor-made materials for diverse applications including gas adsorption, storage, separations, catalysis, sensors, and drug delivery, among others.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) constitute a novel class of open-framework crystalline solids formed by cooperative assembly of metal cations or clusters (termed secondary building units or SBU) with organic linkers. Because the SBUs can have certain preferred coordination geometries, self-assembly of these connecting building units with organic ligands of a particular shape, can lead to the development of MOFs with predictable structures. This is the foundation of the so-called "reticular chemistry" approach and represents an important synthetic tool toward the development of MOFs with predetermined structures and pore systems in terms of size, shape, and functionality. It is now well-documented that MOFs can be truly designed and therefore provide unique opportunities for developing tailor-made materials for diverse applications including gas adsorption, storage, separations, catalysis, sensors, and drug delivery, among others.

elements.content: For the development of functional MOFs, and in particular for gas storage/separation applications and catalysis, the combination of unsaturated metal sites (UMS), acting as strong Lewis acid sites and various polar groups anchored on the organic part of the structure, is a very successful strategy. The designed synthesis of MOFs with UMS relies on the particular choice of the organic linker and metal cation, following specific rules of reticular chemistry. A representative example is the dimeric Cu­(II)-based SBU that offers two UMS one for each Cu­(II). This SBU is readily formed in situ when Cu­(II) cations are reacted with isophthalate-based linkers. Depending on the geometry and connectivity of this kind of organic linkers, different families of MOFs with a specific topology, could be readily synthesized. These include the nbo, rht, tbo, and she families based on rectangular tetratopic, trigonal hexatopic, rectangular octatopic, and hexagonal hexatopic organic linkers, respectively. We emphasize that a particular topology is related to specific pore architecture in terms of size, shape, and connectivity and plays an important role in the overall material’s performance. These Cu-based MOFs represent an important family of porous solids with excellent gas sorption/separation properties, and in particular for hydrogen, acetylene, carbon dioxide and methane.

elements.content: Another important inorganic SBU that readily provides UMS is the trimeric oxo-centered clusters with chemical formula M3(μ3-Ο)­(−COO)6 known for s- (Mg2+), d- (Cr3+, Fe3+), and p-block (Al3+, In3+) elements. This SBU possesses a trigonal prismatic linking geometry and is compatible with the augmented soc (square-octahedron), binodal edge-transitive net. The designed synthesis of this important type of MOFs requires rectangular, 4-connected (4-c) organic linkers.

This SBU possesses a trigonal prismatic linking geometry and is compatible with the augmented soc (square-octahedron), binodal edge-transitive net. The designed synthesis of this important type of MOFs requires rectangular, 4-connected (4-c) organic linkers.

elements.content: We recently reported the use of the palladated 4-c metallo-linker (H4 L), shown in a, that was designed to afford a copper-based nbo type MOF. This novel MOF shows a remarkable CO2 uptake (9 mmol g–1 at 273 K and 1 bar) due to the synergistic effect of Cu­(II) UMS acting as Lewis acid sites and Pd­(II) acting as Lewis base sites. It is evident that the use of this kind of metallo-linkers in reticular synthesis of MOFs, opens new pathways for the construction of a family of porous solids that will combine a particular topology with an additional pore functionality, originating from the presence of Pd­(II) sites. To demonstrate this, we present here the first MOF with soc topology using the palladated linker H4 L based on the trimeric SBU In3(μ3-Ο)­(−COO)6Cl, denoted hereafter as 1. In addition, a slight modification of the synthetic conditions resulted in a novel MOF with PtS type structure, featuring pseudotetrahedral single In­(III) cations as the inorganic nodes, denoted as 2. We have successfully activated 1 and report extensive sorption studies of important gases including carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen. The results show that activated 1 has high CO2 uptake (92.3 cm3 g–1 at 1 bar and 273 K) with moderate isosteric heat of adsorption at zero coverage (29.8 kJ mol–1) and high CO2/CH4 (15.4, 50:50 molar mixture), CO2/N2 (131.7, 10:90 molar mixture) selectivity at 273 K and 1 bar.

InCl3 (≥98%) and tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99.9%) were purchased from Aldrich, [Pd­(PhCN)2Cl2] (99%) from Strem Chemicals, pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC, 98%) from Alfa Aesar, whereas N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, ≥99.8%) from Merck. The palladated linker trans -[PdCl2(PDC)2] (H4 L) was synthesized according to a published procedure.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were purchased from commercial suppliers and used as received. InCl3 (≥98%) and tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99.9%) were purchased from Aldrich, [Pd(PhCN)2Cl2] (99%) from Strem Chemicals, pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC, 98%) from Alfa Aesar, whereas N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, ≥99.8%) from Merck. The palladated linker trans -[PdCl2(PDC)2] (H4 L) was synthesized according to a published procedure.

elements.content: A solid mixture of H4 L (112.5 mg, 0.22 mmol) and InCl3 (116.8 mg, 0.53 mmol) was dissolved in 56 mL of THF/DMF/H2O (4:3:1) in a round-bottomed flask after vigorous magnetic stirring at room temperature for several minutes. The resulting yellow solution was dispensed evenly into 10 scintillation vials (8 mL size), which were sealed and placed in an isothermal oven at 65 °C for 3 days. During this period, high-quality yellow cubic crystals of 1, suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis, were deposited. After cooling the vials to room temperature, the crystals were removed by decanting with mother liquor, samples merged into one batch and washed in fresh DMF (3 × 8 mL per day) for 3 days. For solvent exchange and evacuation, see the activation process below. Yield (of desolvated 1): 121 mg, 30% based on H4 L. FT-IR (neat solid): 1618, 1570, 1447, 1355, 1134, 832, 764, 721, 680, 556, 447, 413.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

[In3O(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]⋅n(solv) (1)

A solid mixture of H4 L (112.5 mg, 0.22 mmol) and InCl3 (116.8 mg, 0.53 mmol) was dissolved in 56 mL of THF/DMF/H2O (4:3:1) in a round-bottomed flask after vigorous magnetic stirring at room temperature for several minutes. The resulting yellow solution was dispensed evenly into 10 scintillation vials (8 mL size), which were sealed and placed in an isothermal oven at 65 °C for 3 days. During this period, high-quality yellow cubic crystals of 1, suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis, were deposited. After cooling the vials to room temperature, the crystals were removed by decanting with mother liquor, samples merged into one batch and washed in fresh DMF (3 × 8 mL per day) for 3 days. For solvent exchange and evacuation, see the activation process below. Yield (of desolvated 1): 121 mg, 30% based on H4 L. FT-IR (neat solid): 1618, 1570, 1447, 1355, 1134, 832, 764, 721, 680, 556, 447, 413.

elements.content: First, 34.1 mg of H4 L (0.067 mmol) and 3 equiv of InCl3 (44.2 mg, 0.200 mmol) were partially dissolved in 10 mL of DMF containing 1 drop of H2O in a scintillation vial (20 mL size). The solution was sonicated for 2 min and then placed in an isothermal oven at 65 °C for 3 days, which induced the precipitation of the product as yellow microcrystalline solid. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was washed by decanting the mother liquor and adding fresh DMF (3 × 8 mL per day) for 3 days. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with acetone (3 × 5 mL), and vacuum-dried. Yield (of desolvated 2): 27 mg, 65% based on H4 L.
elements.clean_text:
[Me2NH2][In(L)]⋅n(solv) (2)

Method A

First, 34.1 mg of H4 L (0.067 mmol) and 3 equiv of InCl3 (44.2 mg, 0.200 mmol) were partially dissolved in 10 mL of DMF containing 1 drop of H2O in a scintillation vial (20 mL size). The solution was sonicated for 2 min and then placed in an isothermal oven at 65 °C for 3 days, which induced the precipitation of the product as yellow microcrystalline solid. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was washed by decanting the mother liquor and adding fresh DMF (3 × 8 mL per day) for 3 days. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with acetone (3 × 5 mL), and vacuum-dried. Yield (of desolvated 2): 27 mg, 65% based on H4 L.

elements.content:
Crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained when the above reaction was performed in 10 mL of DMF/CH3CN (1:1) solution containing a drop of H2O.

Structural CharacterizationSingle-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Data were collected at the X-ray diffraction beamline (XRD1) of the Elettra Synchrotron, Trieste (Italy), with a Pilatus 2 M hybrid-pixel area detector. Complete data sets were collected at 250 K (nitrogen stream supplied through an Oxford Cryostream 700) with a monochromatic wavelength of 0.700 Å through the rotating crystal method. The crystals of 1 and 2 were dipped in N-paratone and mounted on the goniometer head with a nylon loop. The diffraction data were indexed, integrated, and scaled using XDS. The structure was solved by direct methods using SIR2014, Fourier analyzed and refined by the full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 implemented in SHELXL-2014. The Coot program was used for modeling. Anisotropic thermal motion modeling was then applied to all atoms. Restrains on bond distances and thermal motion of disordered groups have been applied (DFIX, DANG, DELU). Hydrogen atoms were included (except for disordered water molecules) at calculated positions with isotropic U factors = 1.2·U eq (or U factors = 1.5·U eq for water molecule in 1). A region of diffuse disordered electron density has been identified inside cavities, filled by randomly oriented solvent molecules and also [Me2NH2]+ counterions for the structure of 2. The contribution of this region to the scattering has been removed with the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON and corresponds to ca. 1358 electrons/cell in a volume of ca. 5553 Å3 for 1 and ca. 395 electrons/cell in a volume of ca. 1461 Å3 for 2. Essential crystal and refinement data together are reported in Table S1; the reported formula mass and unit-cell characteristics do not take into account this disordered electron density.

The structure was solved by direct methods using SIR2014, Fourier analyzed and refined by the full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 implemented in SHELXL-2014. The Coot program was used for modeling. Anisotropic thermal motion modeling was then applied to all atoms. Restrains on bond distances and thermal motion of disordered groups have been applied (DFIX, DANG, DELU). elements.content: Spectra were collected using sealed glass capillaries on an Image Plate R-AXIS IV detector mounted on a Rigaku Ru–H3RHB rotating anode X-ray generator with a belt drive rotating anode (1.5418 Å) operated at 50 kV and 100 mA. The program Mercury (CCDC) was used to obtain calculated PXRD patterns from the corresponding single crystal data.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction Patterns (PXRD)

Spectra were collected using sealed glass capillaries on an Image Plate R-AXIS IV detector mounted on a Rigaku Ru-H3RHB rotating anode X-ray generator with a belt drive rotating anode (1.5418 Å) operated at 50 kV and 100 mA. The program Mercury (CCDC) was used to obtain calculated PXRD patterns from the corresponding single crystal data.

elements.content: Measurements were performed using a SETARAM SETSYS Evolution 18 Analyzer, in the range of 25–900 °C, with a heating rate of 5 °C/min in an Al2O3 crucible under Argon flow (16 mL min–1). Argon purging was always applied well before initiating the measurements to efficiently control the sample environment within the furnace. In addition, buoyancy corrections were carried out through blank measurements. Analysis was performed in both as-synthesized (1) and activated (1a) samples.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

Measurements were performed using a SETARAM SETSYS Evolution 18 Analyzer, in the range of 25-900 °C, with a heating rate of 5 °C/min in an Al2O3 crucible under Argon flow (16 mL min-1). Argon purging was always applied well before initiating the measurements to efficiently control the sample environment within the furnace. In addition, buoyancy corrections were carried out through blank measurements. Analysis was performed in both as-synthesized (1) and activated (1a) samples.

elements.content:
Analyses were carried out using a JEOL JSM-6390LV microscope equipped with the Oxford EDS detector.

FT-IR

Spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were obtained neat using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer equipped with an Attenuated Total Reflectance accessory (ATR) with a diamond crystal (Smart Orbit).

<sup>1</sup>H NMR

Spectra were recorded on a 500 MHz Bruker Avance spectrometer. Samples were prepared by digesting a small portion of the degassed solid with a drop of HCl 37% in a DMSO-d6 solution.

Gas Sorption Measurements

Systematic physical adsorption studies of nitrogen, argon, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and methane as adsorbates were performed over a wide range of temperatures (77–323 K) at low pressures (up to 1 bar). The sorption measurements were carried out on an Autosorb 1-MP instrument from Quantachrome equipped with multiple pressure transducers for high-resolution measurements, a closed-cycle helium cryocooler for accurate temperature control and an oil-free high vacuum system.
elements.clean_text:
Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) Imaging and Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS)

Analyses were carried out using a JEOL JSM-6390LV microscope equipped with the Oxford EDS detector.

FT-IR

Spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were obtained neat using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer equipped with an Attenuated Total Reflectance accessory (ATR) with a diamond crystal (Smart Orbit).

 1H NMR

Spectra were recorded on a 500 MHz Bruker Avance spectrometer. Samples were prepared by digesting a small portion of the degassed solid with a drop of HCl 37% in a DMSO-d6 solution.

Gas Sorption Measurements

Systematic physical adsorption studies of nitrogen, argon, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and methane as adsorbates were performed over a wide range of temperatures (77-323 K) at low pressures (up to 1 bar). The sorption measurements were carried out on an Autosorb 1-MP instrument from Quantachrome equipped with multiple pressure transducers for high-resolution measurements, a closed-cycle helium cryocooler for accurate temperature control and an oil-free high vacuum system.

elements.content: Ultra-high-purity N2 (99.999%), Ar (99.999%), H2 (99.9999%), CO2 (99.998%), and CH4 (99.9995%) were used for all adsorption measurements. Prior to analysis, as-made samples were soaked in methanol at room temperature for 3 days; during each day the supernatant solution was replaced 6 times. The methanol suspended samples were transferred inside the chamber of a custom-made supercritical CO2 dryer and methanol was exchanged with liquid CO2 over a period of 1.5 h at room temperature and under constant flow of 1.5 mL min–1 at 120 bar. Subsequently, the temperature of the pressurized system was raised to 50 °C (above the critical temperature of CO2), kept there for 1.5 h (under the same flow) and was then slowly vented in a controlled manner. The chamber was sealed and transferred to an MBraun Argon filled glovebox, where the dried sample was transferred inside a preweighed, 6 mm cell. The cell was then attached to the outgassing station where the sample was evacuated under dynamic vacuum at room temperature until the out-gas rate was less than 2 mTorr/min. The sample and cell were then reweighed to obtain the mass of the evacuated sample, and the cell was attached to the analysis port of the gas adsorption instrument.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction between the metalloligand trans-[PdCl2(PDC)2] (H4 L) and InCl3 in a THF/DMF/H2O solution mixture afforded [In3O­(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]·n(solv) (1) as yellow cubic crystals of suitable quality for singe-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis. The composition of as-synthesized 1 was also confirmed by TGA, EDS and elemental analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Solvothermal reaction between the metalloligand trans-[PdCl2(PDC)2] (H4 L) and InCl3 in a THF/DMF/H2O solution mixture afforded [In3O(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]⋅n(solv) (1) as yellow cubic crystals of suitable quality for singe-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis. The composition of as-synthesized 1 was also confirmed by TGA, EDS and elemental analysis.

elements.content: SCXRD study reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the cubic system (space group Pm3̅n), with a lattice parameter a = 22.719(5) Å (V = 11726(8) Å3) (Table S1). The structure of 1 is made of oxo-centered trimeric indium clusters linked by L 4– linkers, as shown in . The clusters contain three octahedrally coordinated In­(III) cations sharing one central oxo-anion located on a C 3 axis, resulting in In–(μ3-O)–In angles of 120°. In each octahedron, the In­(III) is coordinated by four different carboxylate groups and one μ3-O atom, while the apical site is occupied by 2/3 of a terminal water molecule and 1/3 of a chloride ion (see Figure S1). The trimeric clusters are bridged together by six different metalloligands L, resulting in an extended three-dimensional structure. Essentially, six metalloligands L, which can be simplified as 4-c node with a rectangular planar geometry (a), sitting on the faces of a cube and connect the eight corners occupied by In3O trimers, each of which can be considered as a 6-c node with a trigonal prismatic geometry (b). This kind of assembly results in the construction of a (4,6)-connected structure with the augmented soc net (c,d). This net comprises of a periodic arrangement of cages and channels (Figure S2), both of which are decorated with −PdCl2– moieties with the Cl– anions being disordered over two positions (Figure S3). The cages have a diameter of 11.2 Å (excluding the van der Waals radii) and are accessible only through small trapezoidal-shaped windows (window dimensions are 7.9 Å × 4.8 Å). Correspondingly, there are two infinite intersecting channels (A and B) with approximate diameter of 4.7 and 5.3 Å, respectively, that are dominated by the presence of coordinated Cl– ions pointing inside the channels (Figure S2). Using PLATON software, the total solvent accessible volume for 1 is calculated to be 52%. The high phase purity of the sample was confirmed from the excellent agreement between the experimental PXRD pattern of 1 and the calculated PXRD pattern from the single crystal structure ().
elements.clean_text: SCXRD study reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the cubic system (space group Pm3̅n), with a lattice parameter a = 22.719(5) Å (V = 11726(8) Å3) (Table S1). The structure of 1 is made of oxo-centered trimeric indium clusters linked by L  4-  linkers, as shown in . The clusters contain three octahedrally coordinated In(III) cations sharing one central oxo-anion located on a C 3 axis, resulting in In-(μ3-O)-In angles of 120°. In each octahedron, the In(III) is coordinated by four different carboxylate groups and one μ3-O atom, while the apical site is occupied by 2/3 of a terminal water molecule and 1/3 of a chloride ion (see Figure S1). The trimeric clusters are bridged together by six different metalloligands L, resulting in an extended three-dimensional structure. Essentially, six metalloligands L, which can be simplified as 4-c node with a rectangular planar geometry (a), sitting on the faces of a cube and connect the eight corners occupied by In3O trimers, each of which can be considered as a 6-c node with a trigonal prismatic geometry (b). This kind of assembly results in the construction of a (4,6)-connected structure with the augmented soc net (c,d). This net comprises of a periodic arrangement of cages and channels (Figure S2), both of which are decorated with -PdCl2- moieties with the Cl- anions being disordered over two positions (Figure S3). The cages have a diameter of 11.2 Å (excluding the van der Waals radii) and are accessible only through small trapezoidal-shaped windows (window dimensions are 7.9 Å × 4.8 Å). Correspondingly, there are two infinite intersecting channels (A and B) with approximate diameter of 4.7 and 5.3 Å, respectively, that are dominated by the presence of coordinated Cl- ions pointing inside the channels (Figure S2). Using PLATON software, the total solvent accessible volume for 1 is calculated to be 52%. The high phase purity of the sample was confirmed from the excellent agreement between the experimental PXRD pattern of 1 and the calculated PXRD pattern from the single crystal structure ().

elements.content: The morphology of the crystals of 1 and its elemental composition was studied by SEM/EDS. SEM images showed that the crystals are well-defined cubes of 10–50 μm in size (Figure S7). The corresponding EDS spectra confirm the presence of palladium, chloride and indium atoms with Pd/Cl/In ratio of 1:2.67:1.81, which is very close to the ratio obtained from the SCXRD analysis (ratio is 1:2.67:2) (Figure S8).

elements.content: The IR spectrum of dried 1 exhibits the bands characteristic of the asymmetric (νas(COO) = 1618 and 1570 cm–1) and symmetric (νs(COO) = 1355 cm–1) carboxylate stretching vibrations of coordinated L (Figure S13). These bands show a bathochromic effect, with respect to the νC=O stretch (1715 cm–1) of the free metalloligand L, due to the coordination of the oxygen atoms on the In­(III) centers.

elements.content: The thermal stability of as-synthesized 1 was investigated by TGA. Upon heating, 1 loses weight in two steps, and the process is completed at 650 °C (Figure S14). A weight loss of 20% occurs below 210 °C, corresponding to solvent evaporation. Above 310 °C weight loss is associated with structural breakdown as the metalloligand decomposes.

elements.content: In terms of chemical stability, 1 is stable in common organic solvents, including DMF, methanol, and acetone, but decomposes in chloroform (Figure S15). On the contrary, a crystalline-to-crystalline transformation was observed when 1 was treated with H2O, as evidenced by the PXRD pattern (Figure S15) and SEM/EDS analysis (Figures S9 and S10). Attempts to obtain single-crystal XRD data of acceptable quality, as well as efforts to activate this new material, were unsuccessful.

elements.content: During the attempts to optimize the synthetic conditions of 1, a crystalline material with a different PXRD pattern compared to that of 1 was isolated. In particular, when DMF containing a drop of H2O was used as a solvent system (method A), solvated framework complex [Me2NH2]­[In­(L)]·n(solv) (2) was afforded as a microcrystalline solid. In contrast, good quality single crystals were harvested when the reaction was executed in the presence of CH3CN (method B). However, the final product was found to be contaminated with metallic palladium, presumably from a partial decomposition of the linker, while the reaction yield was lower.

In particular, when DMF containing a drop of H2O was used as a solvent system (method A), solvated framework complex [Me2NH2][In(L)]⋅n(solv) (2) was afforded as a microcrystalline solid. In contrast, good quality single crystals were harvested when the reaction was executed in the presence of CH3CN (method B). However, the final product was found to be contaminated with metallic palladium, presumably from a partial decomposition of the linker, while the reaction yield was lower.

elements.content: SCXRD analysis shows that compound 2 crystallizes in the tetragonal system (space group P42/mmc) with unit cell parameters a = b = 9.974(5) Å, c = 22.722(10) Å and V = 2260(2) Å3 (Table S1). It is made of mononuclear [In­(−COO)4]− complexes linked with the tetratopic metalloligand L. Each In­(III) is 8-coordinated by four chelating carboxylate groups from four different linkers, forming a 4-c pseudotetrahedral node (a). Every linker serves as a 4-c rectangular node (b) and bridges four different In­(III) cations, forming a three-dimensional (4,4)-c framework with a PtS topology. Compound 2 possesses three distinct 1D intersecting channels, designated as A–C in . The structure features square-shaped channels (channels C), running along the crystallographic c-axis (c,d), with an approximate diameter of 6.7 Å (taking into account the Cl atoms and excluding vdW radii; square’s edge excluding Cl ions is 9.974 Å). These channels are connected together by quadrangular windows made by four In­(III) sites and four ligands (channels A). Furthermore, looking down the a- or b-axes, these channels are interlinked by nearly square windows composed of two In­(III) sites and two metalloligands (channels B) (Figure S4). As in 1, all channels integrate −PdCl2– units with the two Cl– anions being disordered over two positions (Figure S3). Contrary to 1, the framework in 2 is anionic, i.e., −1 per molecular unit. We consider that disordered Me2NH2 + ions formed by the well-known decarbonylation of DMF are acting as counterions. Therefore, the charge-balanced framework formula is (Me2NH2)­InL. The void volume in 2 was estimated by PLATON to be 66%. However, this void contains also the disordered Me2NH2 + counterions; therefore, the actual solvent accessible volume is anticipated to be smaller. The experimental PXRD pattern of 2 matches the corresponding PXRD pattern calculated from the single crystal structure and confirms phase purity ().

elements.content: Attempts to activate 1 under conventional methods, i.e., by solvent exchange and thermal evacuation under reduced pressure proved to be unsuccessful, as evidenced by N2 sorption studies at 77 K. Successful activation was achieved using a supercritical CO2 drying (SCD) methodology. The removal of all solvent molecules while maintaining structural integrity was evaluated by 1H NMR, PXRD, and TGA measurements. The PXRD pattern reveals a high crystallinity and confirms that the structure remains intact after removal of all solvent molecules (). The TGA analysis of activated 1, hereafter labeled as 1a, shows a weight loss of ca. 10% up to 200 °C attributed to the coordinated H2O molecules on the indium trimer, followed by structural breakdown after 320 °C (Figure S14). 1H NMR spectroscopy confirmed as well the absence of solvent molecules in 1a (Figure S16).
elements.clean_text:
Activation Process

Attempts to activate 1 under conventional methods, i.e., by solvent exchange and thermal evacuation under reduced pressure proved to be unsuccessful, as evidenced by N2 sorption studies at 77 K. Successful activation was achieved using a supercritical CO2 drying (SCD) methodology. The removal of all solvent molecules while maintaining structural integrity was evaluated by 1H NMR, PXRD, and TGA measurements. The PXRD pattern reveals a high crystallinity and confirms that the structure remains intact after removal of all solvent molecules (). The TGA analysis of activated 1, hereafter labeled as 1a, shows a weight loss of ca. 10% up to 200 °C attributed to the coordinated H2O molecules on the indium trimer, followed by structural breakdown after 320 °C (Figure S14). 1H NMR spectroscopy confirmed as well the absence of solvent molecules in 1a (Figure S16).

elements.content: Contrary to 1, all attempts to activate 2 including thermal activation, solvent exchange in combination with thermal activation, or extraction with supercritical CO2 failed and resulted in structural collapse. Thus, compound 2 was excluded from further sorption studies.
elements.clean_text: Contrary to 1, all attempts to activate 2 including thermal activation, solvent exchange in combination with thermal activation, or extraction with supercritical CO2 failed and resulted in structural collapse. Thus, compound 2 was excluded from further sorption studies.

elements.content: Nitrogen and argon sorption isotherm of 1a recorded at 77 and 87 K respectively, revealed fully reversible type-I curves characteristic of a microporous material (Figure S17). The BET and Langmuir areas, calculated from the nitrogen isotherm in the pressure range 0.006–0.06 p/p 0 using consistency criteria, were found to be 795 m2 g–1 (Figure S18) and 851 m2 g–1, respectively. The corresponding results extracted from the Argon isotherm are fully consistent (Figures S19 and S20). The very good agreement between the experimentally determined total pore volume (0.35 cm3 g–1 at 0.99 p/p 0 from N2 isotherm) and the corresponding theoretical value calculated from the crystal structure (0.40 cm3 g–1), suggest that the material remains practically intact after activation. The non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) pore size distribution curve, calculated from the Ar adsorption isotherm using a suitable kernel (cylindrical argon–zeolite), displays a main peak centered at 5.8 Å (Figured S21 and S22). This result is in full agreement with the pore size expected from the single crystal structure.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

Nitrogen and argon sorption isotherm of 1a recorded at 77 and 87 K respectively, revealed fully reversible type-I curves characteristic of a microporous material (Figure S17). The BET and Langmuir areas, calculated from the nitrogen isotherm in the pressure range 0.006-0.06 p/p 0 using consistency criteria, were found to be 795 m2 g-1 (Figure S18) and 851 m2 g-1, respectively. The corresponding results extracted from the Argon isotherm are fully consistent (Figures S19 and S20). The very good agreement between the experimentally determined total pore volume (0.35 cm3 g-1 at 0.99 p/p 0 from N2 isotherm) and the corresponding theoretical value calculated from the crystal structure (0.40 cm3 g-1), suggest that the material remains practically intact after activation. The non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) pore size distribution curve, calculated from the Ar adsorption isotherm using a suitable kernel (cylindrical argon-zeolite), displays a main peak centered at 5.8 Å (Figured S21 and S22). This result is in full agreement with the pore size expected from the single crystal structure.

elements.content: The important structural and chemical features of 1a which include the interconnected cages decorated with exposed In-sites resulting from the removal of coordinated H2O molecules, as well as the presence of – PdCl2– moieties, make this material very promising for selective CO2 adsorption and H2 storage. For this reason, CO2, CH4, N2, and H2 gas-sorption isotherms were recorded at various temperatures up to 1 bar, from which key properties such as the total uptake, isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) and IAST selectivity, were calculated.

For this reason, CO2, CH4, N2, and H2 gas-sorption isotherms were recorded at various temperatures up to 1 bar, from which key properties such as the total uptake, isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) and IAST selectivity, were calculated.

elements.content: As shown in and S23, a high CO2 uptake is observed reaching 92.3 cm3 g–1 (4.1 mmol g–1, 18.1 wt %), 77.2 cm3 g–1 (3.4 mmol g–1, 15.2 wt %), and 65.8 cm3 g–1 (2.9 mmol g–1, 12.9 wt %) at 273, 283, and 293 K, respectively, at 1 bar. Considering the gravimetric uptake of 1a at 273 K and 1 bar (92.3 cm3 g–1), there is a limited number of MOFs with higher gravimetric CO2 capacity. This value is also comparable with that of the prototype In-soc-MOF (91.1 cm3 g–1) (or CPM-200-In, 109.6 cm3 g–1) with very similar porosity (BET area 888 m2 g–1, pore volume 0.44 cm3 g–1), based on the organic linker 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid. Compared with our recently reported Cu-based MOF (201.8 cm3 g–1 at 273 K/1 bar), denoted as NbO-Pd-1 (BET surface area 1568 m2 g–1, pore volume 0.60 cm3 g–1, and ρxlt = 0.93 g cm–3) using the same organic linker, the lower gravimetric CO2 capacity is mainly due to the significantly lower BET surface area and total pore volume of 1a. In terms of volumetric capacity (calculated using the crystal density of 1a, 1.31 g cm–3) which is also very important for applications, the corresponding values are 120.9, 101.1, and 86.2 cm3 cm–3 at 273, 283, and 293 K, respectively. The observed uptake at 273 K/1 bar (120.9 cm3 cm–3) is comparable to the corresponding values of some top performing MOFs, including NJU-Bai21 (121.2 cm3 cm–3 at 273 K/1 bar) and Cu-TPBTM (135.9 cm3 cm–3 at 273 K/1 bar).

elements.content: Using the isotherms recorded at 273, 283, and 293 K and applying a virial type fitting, the calculated isosteric heat of adsorption, Q st, is 29.8 kJ mol–1 at zero coverage (Q st 0) and as a function of surface coverage remains almost constant, suggesting a uniform potential landscape in the pores of 1a (Figure S27). Interestingly, the observed Q st 0 value is higher compared to that of NbO-Pd-1 (23.5 kJ mol–1); however, it is lower compared to those of other high performance MOFs including CPM-200 (Fe/Mg, 34.3 kJ mol–1), Cu-TDPAT (42.2 kJ mol–1), and Mg-MOF-74 (47 kJ mol–1). A lower Q st 0 value is preferable for practical applications due to the anticipated energy efficient regeneration.

elements.content: These findings suggest that 1a would be interesting for CO2 selective capture applications where the concentration is moderately high, such as in biogas purification and syngas processes. Accordingly, CH4 adsorption isotherms were also measured (Figure S24) from which Q st and IAST selectivity (CO2/CH4) were determined. At zero coverage, the Q st 0 values is 19.6 kJ mol–1 (Figure S28), which is lower compared to that of NbO-Pd-1 (22.5 kJ mol–1). At 273 K and 1 bar, the predicted CO2/CH4 selectivity for a 5:95 molar mixture is 11.7 (a) which is higher compared to that of NbO-Pd-1 (8.5), due to the Q st 0 values, being simultaneously higher for CO2 and lower for CH4, in 1a. As a function of CO2/CH4 composition, the selectivity is increasing with increasing gas phase CO2 concentration (a and S30). Accordingly, for comparison purposes, for a 50:50 molar ratio, the selectivity at 273 K and 1 bar is 15.4, while at 293 K, it is 10.8 (a). These values compare well with some representative MOFs, including NJU-Bai21 (7.8 at 298 K), Bio-MOF-11 (12 at 298 K), and Cu-TDPAT (20 at 298 K). In addition, a N2 isotherm at 273 K was recorded (Figure S25), and the calculated CO2/N2 IAST selectivity is 58.6 for a 5:95 mixture at low pressure (100 mmHg) and reaches 92 at 1 bar (b). This selectivity is increasing with increasing the CO2/N2 molar mixture, reaching at low pressure (100 mmHg) 63.7, 71.5, 79.2, and 96.7 for 10:20, 20:80, 30:70, and 50:50 molar mixtures, respectively (b and S31). The corresponding values at 1 bar are 131.7, 271.1, 546.1, and 1946.8 (Figure S31). These values are higher than IAST selectivities of many other MOFs and compare well with some those of high-performing materials including those in the CPM-200 soc-type family, UTSA-49a, and NJU-Bai23.

elements.content: Finally, the hydrogen storage properties of 1a were also investigated. Accordingly, the gravimetric and volumetric uptake at 77 K and 1 bar are 143.9 cm3 g–1 (6.4 mmol g–1, 1.28 wt %) and 188.5 cm3 cm–3, respectively (Figure S26). The Q st 0 value calculated from the corresponding isotherms at 77, 90, and 100 K is 7.1 kJ mol–1 and as a function of surface coverage remains almost constant (Figure S29). The observed Q st 0 value is higher with respect to the prototype In-soc MOF, however the latter shows higher gravimetric uptake (2.6 wt %) due to the combination of higher porosity and lower crystal density.

elements.content: Palladated organic linker H4 L was successfully utilized for the construction of a new member in the important family of MOFs with soc topology. Accordingly, the new In-based material features the unique pore structure of soc-type MOFs decorated with −PdCl2– moieties. This kind of complex heterometallic MOF offers great opportunities for numerous key applications including gas storage and separations. We have successfully activated this MOF and measured its CO2, CH4, N2, and H2 sorption properties. A high gravimetric and volumetric CO2 uptake is observed reaching 92.3 cm3 g–1 (120.9 cm3 cm–3) at 273 K/1 bar as well as high CO2/CH4 (15.4 for a 50:50 molar mixture) and CO2/N2 (131.7 for a 10:90 molar mixture) selectivity, with moderate Q st 0 for CO2 (29.8 kJ mol–1). A relatively high Q st 0 for H2 (7.1 kJ mol–1) is also observed with moderate uptake at 77 K/1 bar (1.28 wt %). Under different synthesis conditions, a PtS-type MOF is isolated in which single In­(III) cations serve as pseudotetrahedral nodes. This MOF has an anionic framework that was not yet possible to activate.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Palladated organic linker H4 L was successfully utilized for the construction of a new member in the important family of MOFs with soc topology. Accordingly, the new In-based material features the unique pore structure of soc-type MOFs decorated with -PdCl2- moieties. This kind of complex heterometallic MOF offers great opportunities for numerous key applications including gas storage and separations. cln_elements.content:
A solid mixture of H4 L (112.5 mg, 0.22 mmol) and InCl3 (116.8 mg, 0.53 mmol) was dissolved in 56 mL of THF/DMF/H2O (4:3:1) in a round-bottomed flask after vigorous magnetic stirring at room temperature for several minutes. The resulting yellow solution was dispensed evenly into 10 scintillation vials (8 mL size), which were sealed and placed in an isothermal oven at 65 °C for 3 days. During this period, high-quality yellow cubic crystals of 1, suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis, were deposited. After cooling the vials to room temperature, the crystals were removed by decanting with mother liquor, samples merged into one batch and washed in fresh DMF (3 × 8 mL per day) for 3 days. For solvent exchange and evacuation, see the activation process below. Yield (of desolvated 1): 121 mg, 30% based on H4 L. FT-IR (neat solid): 1618, 1570, 1447, 1355, 1134, 832, 764, 721, 680, 556, 447, 413.

[Me<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]­[In­(<bold>L</bold>)]·<italic>n</italic>(solv) (<bold>2</bold>)Method A

First, 34.1 mg of H4 L (0.067 mmol) and 3 equiv of InCl3 (44.2 mg, 0.200 mmol) were partially dissolved in 10 mL of DMF containing 1 drop of H2O in a scintillation vial (20 mL size). The solution was sonicated for 2 min and then placed in an isothermal oven at 65 °C for 3 days, which induced the precipitation of the product as yellow microcrystalline solid. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was washed by decanting the mother liquor and adding fresh DMF (3 × 8 mL per day) for 3 days. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with acetone (3 × 5 mL), and vacuum-dried. Yield (of desolvated 2): 27 mg, 65% based on H4 L.

cln_elements.content:
We recently reported the use of the palladated 4-c metallo-linker (H4 L), shown in a, that was designed to afford a copper-based nbo type MOF. This novel MOF shows a remarkable CO2 uptake (9 mmol g–1 at 273 K and 1 bar) due to the synergistic effect of Cu­(II) UMS acting as Lewis acid sites and Pd­(II) acting as Lewis base sites. It is evident that the use of this kind of metallo-linkers in reticular synthesis of MOFs, opens new pathways for the construction of a family of porous solids that will combine a particular topology with an additional pore functionality, originating from the presence of Pd­(II) sites. To demonstrate this, we present here the first MOF with soc topology using the palladated linker H4 L based on the trimeric SBU In3(μ3-Ο)­(−COO)6Cl, denoted hereafter as 1. In addition, a slight modification of the synthetic conditions resulted in a novel MOF with PtS type structure, featuring pseudotetrahedral single In­(III) cations as the inorganic nodes, denoted as 2. We have successfully activated 1 and report extensive sorption studies of important gases including carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen. The results show that activated 1 has high CO2 uptake (92.3 cm3 g–1 at 1 bar and 273 K) with moderate isosteric heat of adsorption at zero coverage (29.8 kJ mol–1) and high CO2/CH4 (15.4, 50:50 molar mixture), CO2/N2 (131.7, 10:90 molar mixture) selectivity at 273 K and 1 bar.

The thermal stability of as-synthesized 1 was investigated by TGA. Upon heating, 1 loses weight in two steps, and the process is completed at 650 °C (Figure S14). A weight loss of 20% occurs below 210 °C, corresponding to solvent evaporation. Above 310 °C weight loss is associated with structural breakdown as the metalloligand decomposes.

Activation Process

Attempts to activate 1 under conventional methods, i.e., by solvent exchange and thermal evacuation under reduced pressure proved to be unsuccessful, as evidenced by N2 sorption studies at 77 K. Successful activation was achieved using a supercritical CO2 drying (SCD) methodology. The removal of all solvent molecules while maintaining structural integrity was evaluated by 1H NMR, PXRD, and TGA measurements. The PXRD pattern reveals a high crystallinity and confirms that the structure remains intact after removal of all solvent molecules (). The TGA analysis of activated 1, hereafter labeled as 1a, shows a weight loss of ca. 10% up to 200 °C attributed to the coordinated H2O molecules on the indium trimer, followed by structural breakdown after 320 °C (Figure S14). 1H NMR spectroscopy confirmed as well the absence of solvent molecules in 1a (Figure S16).

Gas Sorption Properties

Nitrogen and argon sorption isotherm of 1a recorded at 77 and 87 K respectively, revealed fully reversible type-I curves characteristic of a microporous material (Figure S17). The BET and Langmuir areas, calculated from the nitrogen isotherm in the pressure range 0.006–0.06 p/p 0 using consistency criteria, were found to be 795 m2 g–1 (Figure S18) and 851 m2 g–1, respectively. The corresponding results extracted from the Argon isotherm are fully consistent (Figures S19 and S20). The very good agreement between the experimentally determined total pore volume (0.35 cm3 g–1 at 0.99 p/p 0 from N2 isotherm) and the corresponding theoretical value calculated from the crystal structure (0.40 cm3 g–1), suggest that the material remains practically intact after activation. The non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) pore size distribution curve, calculated from the Ar adsorption isotherm using a suitable kernel (cylindrical argon–zeolite), displays a main peak centered at 5.8 Å (Figured S21 and S22). This result is in full agreement with the pore size expected from the single crystal structure.

As shown in and S23, a high CO2 uptake is observed reaching 92.3 cm3 g–1 (4.1 mmol g–1, 18.1 wt %), 77.2 cm3 g–1 (3.4 mmol g–1, 15.2 wt %), and 65.8 cm3 g–1 (2.9 mmol g–1, 12.9 wt %) at 273, 283, and 293 K, respectively, at 1 bar. Considering the gravimetric uptake of 1a at 273 K and 1 bar (92.3 cm3 g–1), there is a limited number of MOFs with higher gravimetric CO2 capacity. This value is also comparable with that of the prototype In-soc-MOF (91.1 cm3 g–1) (or CPM-200-In, 109.6 cm3 g–1) with very similar porosity (BET area 888 m2 g–1, pore volume 0.44 cm3 g–1), based on the organic linker 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid. Compared with our recently reported Cu-based MOF (201.8 cm3 g–1 at 273 K/1 bar), denoted as NbO-Pd-1 (BET surface area 1568 m2 g–1, pore volume 0.60 cm3 g–1, and ρxlt = 0.93 g cm–3) using the same organic linker, the lower gravimetric CO2 capacity is mainly due to the significantly lower BET surface area and total pore volume of 1a. In terms of volumetric capacity (calculated using the crystal density of 1a, 1.31 g cm–3) which is also very important for applications, the corresponding values are 120.9, 101.1, and 86.2 cm3 cm–3 at 273, 283, and 293 K, respectively. The observed uptake at 273 K/1 bar (120.9 cm3 cm–3) is comparable to the corresponding values of some top performing MOFs, including NJU-Bai21 (121.2 cm3 cm–3 at 273 K/1 bar) and Cu-TPBTM (135.9 cm3 cm–3 at 273 K/1 bar).

Using the isotherms recorded at 273, 283, and 293 K and applying a virial type fitting, the calculated isosteric heat of adsorption, Q st, is 29.8 kJ mol–1 at zero coverage (Q st 0) and as a function of surface coverage remains almost constant, suggesting a uniform potential landscape in the pores of 1a (Figure S27). Interestingly, the observed Q st 0 value is higher compared to that of NbO-Pd-1 (23.5 kJ mol–1); however, it is lower compared to those of other high performance MOFs including CPM-200 (Fe/Mg, 34.3 kJ mol–1), Cu-TDPAT (42.2 kJ mol–1), and Mg-MOF-74 (47 kJ mol–1). A lower Q st 0 value is preferable for practical applications due to the anticipated energy efficient regeneration.

Finally, the hydrogen storage properties of 1a were also investigated. Accordingly, the gravimetric and volumetric uptake at 77 K and 1 bar are 143.9 cm3 g–1 (6.4 mmol g–1, 1.28 wt %) and 188.5 cm3 cm–3, respectively (Figure S26). The Q st 0 value calculated from the corresponding isotherms at 77, 90, and 100 K is 7.1 kJ mol–1 and as a function of surface coverage remains almost constant (Figure S29). The observed Q st 0 value is higher with respect to the prototype In-soc MOF, however the latter shows higher gravimetric uptake (2.6 wt %) due to the combination of higher porosity and lower crystal density.

Conclusions

Palladated organic linker H4 L was successfully utilized for the construction of a new member in the important family of MOFs with soc topology. Accordingly, the new In-based material features the unique pore structure of soc-type MOFs decorated with −PdCl2– moieties. This kind of complex heterometallic MOF offers great opportunities for numerous key applications including gas storage and separations. We have successfully activated this MOF and measured its CO2, CH4, N2, and H2 sorption properties. A high gravimetric and volumetric CO2 uptake is observed reaching 92.3 cm3 g–1 (120.9 cm3 cm–3) at 273 K/1 bar as well as high CO2/CH4 (15.4 for a 50:50 molar mixture) and CO2/N2 (131.7 for a 10:90 molar mixture) selectivity, with moderate Q st 0 for CO2 (29.8 kJ mol–1). A relatively high Q st 0 for H2 (7.1 kJ mol–1) is also observed with moderate uptake at 77 K/1 bar (1.28 wt %). Under different synthesis conditions, a PtS-type MOF is isolated in which single In­(III) cations serve as pseudotetrahedral nodes. This MOF has an anionic framework that was not yet possible to activate.

metadata.title:
Heterometallic In(III)–Pd(II) Porous Metal–Organic
Framework with Square-Octahedron Topology Displaying High CO2 Uptake and Selectivity toward CH4 and N2
